author: ghost
body:
Steps to reproduce
------------------

```powershell
Import-Module .\build.psm1
Start-PSBootstrap
```

Expected behavior
-----------------

Build completes.

Actual behavior
---------------

```none
PS C:\Users\R0b0t1\Documents\Projects\PowerShell> Start-PSBootstrap
Installing PowerShell build dependencies
WARNING: The 'dotnet' in the current path can't find SDK version 2.1.4, prepending
C:\Users\R0b0t1\AppData\Local\Microsoft\dotnet to PATH.
dotnet not present.  Installing dotnet.
dotnet-install: Downloading link: https://dotnetcli.azureedge.net/dotnet/Sdk/2.1.4/dotnet-sdk-2.1.4-win-x64.zip
dotnet-install: Extracting zip from https://dotnetcli.azureedge.net/dotnet/Sdk/2.1.4/dotnet-sdk-2.1.4-win-x64.zip
dotnet-install: Adding to current process PATH: "C:\Users\R0b0t1\AppData\Local\Microsoft\dotnet\". Note: This change will n
ot be visible if PowerShell was run as a child process.
dotnet-install: Installation finished
pwsh.exe not found. Install latest PowerShell Core release and add it to Path
VERBOSE: Destination: C:\Users\R0b0t1\AppData\Local\Microsoft\powershell
VERBOSE: About to download package from
'https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases/download/v6.0.2/PowerShell-6.0.2-win-x64.zip'
C:\Users\R0b0t1\Documents\Projects\PowerShell\tools\install-powershell.ps1 : Exception calling "SetEnvironmentVariable"
with "3" argument(s): "Requested registry access is not allowed."
At C:\Users\R0b0t1\Documents\Projects\PowerShell\build.psm1:1725 char:17
+                 & $psInstallFile -AddToPath
+                 ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
    + CategoryInfo          : NotSpecified: (:) [install-powershell.ps1], MethodInvocationException
    + FullyQualifiedErrorId : SecurityException,install-powershell.ps1
```

Environment data
----------------

```powershell
> $PSVersionTable
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      5.1.16299.251
PSEdition                      Desktop
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0...}
BuildVersion                   10.0.16299.251
CLRVersion                     4.0.30319.42000
WSManStackVersion              3.0
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
```

Comments
----------------

I am unsure of if I did or not, but I meant to file a bug about a similar issue on Linux, and the circular dependency on PowerShell required during the build.

comments.author: SteveL-MSFT
comments.body: The build script only works with PSCore6.  You can see from the error that it tries to install PSCore6, but fails because you're not running it elevated.  If you rerun `Start-PSBootStrap` elevated, it should install PSCore6 and work correctly.

comments.author: ghost
comments.body: Thanks @SteveL-MSFT; I kind of assumed that was the fix. The issue was opened more because I am wondering why I need to install PSCore6 system wide.

comments.author: SteveL-MSFT
comments.body: @R030t1 the need to install PSCore6 system wide was probably just a simplification of the bootstrapping process and it could be updated to just rely on the zip for single user install rather than require elevation (on Win10 anyways).  However, on downlevel systems (older than Win10) there are some pre-requisites that need to be installed before PSCore6 works which require Windows Updates which would still require elevation so perhaps it's ok to leave it as-is unless it's a huge burden.

title: Unable to Build as User
